verdict.summary: The AI Safety Filter poses compliance risks due to lack of transparency and user appeal options in content removals, as required by the Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021 in India.

issues.title: Lack of Transparent Grievance Redressal System
issues.description: The AI Safety Filter removes content without human review or a transparent grievance redressal system, violating Section 79 of the IT Act that mandates intermediaries to have such a mechanism.
issues.impact: Potential legal action and fines under the IT Act, 2000 as amended by the Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021.
issues.remediation: Implement a transparent and efficient grievance redressal system for content removals.

issues.title: Missing User Consent and Opt-Out Option
issues.description: The feature collects personal data without user consent or an opt-out option, which may raise fairness concerns under the Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019 (currently not enacted).
issues.impact: Potential legal action and fines under the Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019 (currently not enacted).
issues.remediation: Obtain user consent and provide an opt-out option for the AI Safety Filter.

evidence_cited.citation: Information Technology Act, 2000 as amended by the Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021
evidence_cited.content: An intermediary shall not be liable for any third party information, data, or communication link residing on or generated, initiated or transmitted using an intermediary's network or service.

evidence_cited.citation: Personal Data Protection Bill, 2019 (Currently not enacted)
